There have been unseemly tussles with the staff of
the day-care centre van when it comes to collect Mr
D, and Mrs D is embarrassed by the scenes in front of
the house. She is also increasingly exhausted because
she is no longer getting the respite she needs.
Missing the company of the day-care centre
has made Mr D morose and irritable, increasing the
tensions at home. He has also become increasingly
‘
obsessive, muttering that he never has any time any
’
more and complaining that his work burdens seem to
grow and grow. He desperately needs more time at the
office, he says angrily, and blames his wife for being
unable to drive, so that she cannot take him to work.
The ambulance staff have suggested to Mrs D that
she could tell her husband that the van is a taxi,
calling to take him to work. They are sure that the
staff at the centre will go along with the fiction that
’
this is Mr D s new office. These little deceptions hap-
pen all the time with patients like Mr D, they reassure
her: sometimes patients are given medications in
secret at the day-care centre, for example. Somehow
’
Mrs D doesn t actually find this terribly reassuring.
(Based on a case in Hope and Oppenheimer, 1996)
The Case of Mr D
Sixty-eight-year-old Mr D, who has moderate deme-
ntia of the Alzheimer’s type, lives at home with his
wife. He is active and fit, which makes him quite
demanding for Mrs D to nurse, given that he is also
prone to wander and to forget where he lives. She
welcomes the respite given by his attendance at a
day-care centre, which he enjoys: he is very sociable.
Lately, however, Mr D has become worried about
going to the day-care centre because he thinks he is
losing time off work. He has never really stopped
believing that he is still employed, although his
increasing dementia forced him to retire six years
ago. Now he insists that he cannot afford time to
‘ ’
relax because his deadlines at work are too pressing.

data.vignette: Mr D is 68 and has moderate Alzheimer’s dementia. He lives at home with his wife. He is physically fit and often tries to leave the house, then forgets where he lives. A day-care program has kept him engaged and has given his wife needed respite. In recent weeks he has become distressed at pick-up. He insists he must get to his office and says day-care is “wasting time.” He argues with the van staff at the curb and has tried to walk away. The center says it cannot continue transport if the scenes persist. His wife says she is exhausted and cannot keep him safe all day. She asks you for a plan before the next scheduled pick-up. The dementia team notes that either approach is permitted under hospital policy.
data.choice_1: Coordinate with the center to present day-care as his job and transport as a taxi.
data.choice_2: Explain truthfully that he is retired and pause day-care despite his objections.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: The dilemma is currently framed as a practical/behavior-management choice with an implied clinically superior/safer option (“cannot keep him safe all day” makes continuing day-care feel necessary). Rebalance so neither option is implicitly ‘the’ safe/necessary one. For example: (1) Add that home supports could be arranged if day-care is paused (home aide, adult day alternatives, safety devices), but these are imperfect/limited; (2) Add that using deception may worsen paranoia/agitation or undermine trust if discovered, creating clinical and relational risk. Keep these as qualitative, not outcome-optimizing claims.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Choices are not framed as clinician orders and are not fully mutually exclusive (you could be truthful yet still continue day-care with a different plan; you could pause day-care without ‘despite his objections’). Make each a concrete, implementable plan with clear endpoints. Example: Choice 1: ‘Document a therapeutic fib plan; instruct staff to use the job/taxi script; proceed with scheduled pick-up.’ Choice 2: ‘Decline to endorse deception; inform patient he is retired; cancel/hold day-care enrollment for now and initiate alternative supervision plan.’

key_information.suggested_changes: Missing key decision-making facts needed to ground the ethics and feasibility: (1) Mr D’s decision-making capacity for this specific decision (at least a brief statement that he lacks capacity for day-care participation/transport decisions, or that capacity is fluctuating and contested); (2) Any advance directives/prior values about honesty, independence, or being ‘treated like a child’; (3) Safety context (history of getting lost, falls, traffic risk) stated briefly; (4) What ‘pause day-care’ entails (loss of slot? alternative care options?); (5) Whether wife is surrogate/POA. Remove/trim minor details that don’t change the dilemma (e.g., “physically fit” is only needed if it relates to elopement risk—tie it explicitly or drop it).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Several elements need tightening to be medically/operationally realistic: (1) A physician typically can’t unilaterally ‘coordinate with the center’ without consent/role clarity—state that wife is caregiver/surrogate and requests physician guidance, and that the center asks for a written plan. (2) ‘Explain truthfully and pause day-care despite his objections’ is plausible only if he lacks capacity for this decision; otherwise it’s ethically/legally fraught. Add a sentence clarifying capacity and surrogate authority. (3) Clarify that transport refusal risk is about curbside agitation/elopement and staff safety policies, which is plausible.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add explicit legal grounding: who has decision-making authority and that both approaches are permissible. For example: ‘He lacks capacity to decide about adult day services; his wife is his durable power of attorney for health care. Therapeutic fibbing and stopping adult day care are both legally permissible options when used to prevent harm and align with surrogate decisions.’ Avoid jurisdiction-specific claims; keep it general but clear.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the wife’s exhaustion and safety statement makes continuing day-care feel obviously necessary, and the “truthful” option reads like an avoidable harm. To make both defensible: (1) Specify that deception conflicts with Mr D’s longstanding values (e.g., he was adamant about honesty/dignity) and could cause significant distress/anger if uncovered; (2) Specify that pausing day-care may worsen caregiver strain and increase wandering risk, but could preserve trust and reduce confrontations. (3) Add that there is no perfect alternative: home care is limited/expensive, and restraints/sedation are not desired. This keeps the moral cost on both sides.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Strengthen the value clash by making clear that (a) Mr D still has some decision-making capacity about day-care and is consistently refusing/trying to leave, and (b) stopping day-care foreseeably increases concrete risks (wandering, caregiver burnout leading to unsafe supervision or institutionalization) within a short time. Add a sentence clarifying what level of capacity he has and that the physician must choose today because transport will be discontinued after the next incident.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Make the ethical meaning of each option less sensitive to phrasing by specifying the key feature: Choice 1 involves deliberate deception/therapeutic fibbing to obtain cooperation; Choice 2 involves full disclosure and honoring refusal but accepting foreseeable safety/caregiver consequences. Avoid wording that frames Choice 2 as merely 'truthful' (morally loaded) by adding comparable moral language for Choice 1 (e.g., 'use a comforting deception') and for Choice 2 (e.g., 'prioritize honesty even if it leads to stopping the program').

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the central tradeoff and remove ambiguity about why day-care must be paused in Choice 2. As written, it is unclear why truth-telling entails stopping day-care rather than negotiating, changing transport method, or providing an escort. Add a constraint: the center will only accept him if he goes willingly; wife cannot transport; no additional staff/escort is available on short notice. This will make most graders identify the same honesty/respect vs welfare/safety conflict.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Balance the options so neither is an obvious ethical winner. Currently Choice 1 looks like low-harm deception with high benefit, and Choice 2 looks like avoidable harm. Add credible downsides to Choice 1 (risk he discovers the deception and becomes more paranoid/agitated, erosion of trust, potential for escalation/need for restraint) and credible ethical upsides to Choice 2 (preserves trust/relationship, aligns with his expressed values, avoids manipulating him, may enable alternative supports like in-home aide or different program). Also specify that pausing day-care is time-limited while alternatives are arranged, not abandonment.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove value-laden or scene-setting language that nudges sympathy (e.g., change “scenes persist,” “exhausted,” “cannot keep him safe all day” to more clinical, observable descriptions such as “recurrent verbal agitation and attempts to leave during transport; caregiver reports inability to provide continuous supervision”). Avoid framing one option as more reasonable (e.g., “despite his objections”).

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Rewrite in a more clinical style: specify cognitive status (e.g., MMSE/MoCA not required but describe capacity for this decision), agitation/exit-seeking behaviors, safety concerns (wandering risk), and prior nonpharmacologic approaches. Replace colloquial phrases (“wasting time,” “scenes”) with clinical terms (“expresses desire to go to work; becomes agitated at pickup”).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and neutralize the actions to ~10–15 words without extra framing. Example: Choice 1: “Use a therapeutic rationale for daycare and coached transport messaging.” Choice 2: “Provide reality-oriented explanation and discontinue daycare transportation/services.” Remove “truthfully,” “despite his objections,” and specific props like “taxi” unless essential.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make both options comparably defensible and costly. As written, Choice 2 (pause day-care) predictably increases caregiver burnout and elopement risk, making it look clearly worse. Revise Choice 2 to an ethically competing but clinically protective option (e.g., “be fully truthful and set firm limits with a safety plan, including arranging in-home supervision/alternate transport, even if it escalates his distress and risks loss of rapport”). Also add a concrete downside to Choice 1 (e.g., deception has begun to fail, increases paranoia/anger when contradicted, undermines trust with wife/team, or conflicts with his previously stated values about honesty).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle-ground/hybrid options. Currently you could be truthful yet still continue day-care, adjust the pick-up routine, add a 1:1 escort, switch to a different program, trial behavioral/environmental interventions, or add temporary home aide coverage—none are ruled out. To force a true binary, specify a constraint such as: the center will only accept him back if staff can use a ‘job/taxi’ script; otherwise they will discharge him immediately, and no alternative supervision/transport resources can be arranged before the next pick-up. Then frame the choices as (A) authorize the scripted deception to keep the slot, vs (B) refuse deception knowing he will be discharged and must stay home with limited supports.

data.vignette: Mr D is 68 and has moderate Alzheimer’s dementia. He lives with his wife, who is his durable power of attorney for health care. He has recurrent exit-seeking and has previously been found disoriented several blocks from home. An adult day program has provided supervision and structure. Over the past month, he has become agitated at pick-up. He repeatedly states he must get to his office and tries to leave the van area on foot. Staff have asked for a written plan before the next scheduled pick-up tomorrow. They will only continue service if everyone uses a consistent “workday” script; otherwise he will be discharged from the program immediately. Mr D can express preferences but cannot consistently understand or weigh the purpose and risks of attending versus staying home. His wife can arrange limited in-home help, but not by tomorrow, and she cannot safely transport him herself. Hospital policy confirms either approach is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Document a therapeutic “workday” script and proceed with day-care pick-up.
data.choice_2: Decline to endorse deception and cancel day-care attendance starting tomorrow.

choice_1.choice: Document a therapeutic “workday” script and proceed with day-care pick-up.

choice_2.choice: Decline to endorse deception and cancel day-care attendance starting tomorrow.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause stating either (a) Mr D previously said he does not want to be lied to/“tricked,” or (b) his wife (as DPOA) explicitly requests/consents to using a therapeutic script to keep him in day care—so it’s clear whose autonomy is being respected or overridden.

Add a clause clarifying the likely clinical consequences of canceling day-care (e.g., "without day-care, he would be unsupervised for several hours tomorrow, with high risk of elopement/injury and wife burnout"), or explicitly state that his agitation is manageable and day-care is his safest option.

Add a clause that (a) using the scripted story usually prevents his agitation/elopement at pick-up but could distress him if he realizes he’s being misled, and (b) canceling day care leaves him unsupervised tomorrow with high likelihood of wandering/injury because his wife cannot safely manage or transport him.

data.vignette: Mr D is 68 and has moderate Alzheimer’s dementia. He lives with his wife, who is his durable power of attorney for health care. He has recurrent exit-seeking and has previously been found disoriented several blocks from home. An adult day program provides supervision and structure. Over the past month, he has become agitated at pick-up. He repeatedly states he must get to his office and tries to leave the van area on foot. Staff have asked for a written plan before the next scheduled pick-up tomorrow. They will only continue service if everyone uses a consistent “workday” script; otherwise he will be discharged from the program immediately. The scripted story usually reduces his agitation and prevents elopement at pick-up, but he may become distressed if he realizes he is being misled. Mr D can express preferences but cannot consistently understand or weigh the purpose and risks of attending versus staying home. His wife requests using the therapeutic script to keep him enrolled. If day care is canceled tomorrow, he would be unsupervised for several hours, and his wife cannot safely transport him or arrange in-home help on such short notice. Hospital policy confirms either approach is legally permissible.

choice_1.choice: Document a therapeutic “workday” script and proceed with day-care pick-up.

choice_2.choice: Decline to endorse deception and cancel day-care attendance starting tomorrow.
